growthscreener 1.14.0
  • Reference
  • Changelog

    Referral advice for weight for height

    calculate_advice_wgt.Rd

    This function traverses the decision tree of the "JGZ-Richtlijn overgewicht 2012" and "JGZ-Richtlijn Ondergewicht 2019"

    calculate_advice_wgt(
  sex = NA_character_,
  ga = NA,
  etn = NA,
  dom0 = NA_integer_,
  y0 = NA,
  dom1 = NA_integer_,
  y1 = NA,
  hgt1 = NA,
  hgt0 = NA,
  test_gain = TRUE,
  verbose = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    sex

    Character, either "male" or "female"

    ga

    Gestational age, completed weeks (Integer or character)

    etn

    Etnicity, one of "NL" (dutch), "TU" (turkish), "MA" (moroccan) or "HS" (hindustani). The default is "NL". Only used for target height.

    dom0

    Age at previous measurement (days)

    y0

    Height at previous measurement (cm)

    dom1

    Age at last measurement (days)

    y1

    Height at last measurement (cm)

    hgt1

    Height at last measurement (cm)

    hgt0

    Height at previous measurement (cm)

    test_gain

    Logical. Should the increase or decrease in Z-scores be tested? The default is TRUE.

    verbose

    Set to TRUE to obtain warnings on reference finding.

    Value

    calculate_advice_wgt() returns an integer, the msgcode

    Details

    The decision tree assesses both single and paired measurements. The last observations (y1) is generally taken as the last measurement, whereas y0 can be one of the previous measurements. For more than two measurements, there are many pairs possible, and these pairs need not be consecutive. The y0 measurement needs to be defined by the user, and is informally taken as an earlier measurement that maximizes the referral probability.

    Author

    Arjan Huizing, Stef van Buuren 2020

    Examples

    msg(calculate_advice_wgt())
#> [1] "Voer het geslacht in."
msgcode <- calculate_advice_wgt(sex = "male", dom1 = 1441, y1 = 25, hgt1 = 120)
msg(msgcode)
#> [1] "Het advies kan niet worden bepaald. Voer het gewicht bij de eerdere meting in."

    Contents

    Developed by Paula van Dommelen, Stef van Buuren, Arjan Huizing.
